Blurb
Overview
This module provides students with an insight into higher education, the transition from learning to studying, and an appreciation of Biosciences as the bigger picture. All within the context of establishing the solid foundation upon which to build a degree in whichever area of the Life Sciences a student chooses. This module brings together the core concepts of biology and highlights the importance of the roles they play and the interrelationships between the biological disciplines. In this module students will study biology at the macro and micro levels. A mix of learning & teaching methods will be used in this module which will include, but are not limited to lectures, active learning, and learning through assessment, plus the use of directed reading/multimedia resources. This module will be assessed by a cycle 1 'midterm' assessment comprising mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions (30%). Cycle 2 'end of module assessment' is split into two parts: Part A which will be a similar format to the cycle 1 assessment (35%) and Part B which will comprise a data interpretation assessment. (35%).
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

To provide students with the opportunity to develop their knowledge and understanding of the core concepts in biology applicable to the Life Sciences.

To encourage the students to increase their awareness and appreciation of the ‘bigger picture’ related to the study of Bioscience and the interdisciplinary relationships between the Life science disciplines.

To facilitate the development of knowledge and understating of the Life Sciences to enable students to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge, to solve problems and make informed decisions on their future study pathways.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The transition into higher education can be a challenging one. This module aims to aid students in their journey from further education learners into higher education students of the Life Sciences. To truly appreciate the disciplines which make up the Life Sciences we must first develop an understanding and appreciation of their commonalities. This module brings together the core concepts of biology at the macro through the micro levels. This will provide students with the opportunity to develop and enhance their knowledge of the Life Sciences and the possible pathways which they wish to study further. A mix of learning & teaching methods will be used in this module which will include, but are not limited to lectures, active learning, and learning through assessment, plus the use of directed reading/multimedia resources. This module will be assessed by a midterm assessment comprising mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions (30%). There will also be an end of module assessment which is split into two parts: Part A which will be a similar format to the midterm assessment (35%) and Part B which will comprise a data interpretation assessment (35%).
Outline Syllabus
1. What is University about? Biology, the bigger picture and the parts we play, where do we fit in?

2. Themed introduction to the tree of life (microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals)– introductory overviews of commonality in areas such as (but not limited to) genetic codes, metabolism, small molecules and translational information systems. Similarities and differences between various organisms. Major evolutionary transitions and patterns of life over earth history.

3. The flow of information: what makes everything work? – DNA, RNA, Protein; building blocks and molecular underpinnings; metabolism, energy, efficiency and inefficiency.

4. How do cells replicate? – Mitosis, meiosis, mutation; Bacterial replication, binary fission.

5. How to build an organism? – What are the different organisms and their basis; Prokaryotic, Eurokaryotic (microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals). Introductions to microbial diversity. Development and complexity.

6. Genetics and evolution – Genetics, mutation, selection, natural and sexual selection, genetic drift, genetic diversity, AMR, adaptation and limits; micro and macro evolution. Human origins and diversity

7. Microbial diversity – Introductions to virology, parasitology, bacteriology, and the ways of life; Public and Global health.

8. General principles of pharmacology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts as a baseline and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through on-campus lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as per details below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 60 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.  

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be associated with approx. 4 hours of independent learning. This encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning in preparation for lectures, as well as revision study and work towards assessment.
 
The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g., PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g., Padlet, Miro). Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.  

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.
These are in form of in class exercises and online resources which will be available in the VLE.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two summative assessments, with the second split into two components.

a) Assessment 1 (30%): Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the first half of this module (30 sessions). Assessment 1 will be completed online.

b) Assessment 2 (70% in total): This end of module assessment comprises two components: Part A (35%) consists of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the second half of this module (30 sessions). Part B (35%) is a data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. Assessment 2 will be an on-campus exam.

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).   All three assessment components will contribute to the final module mark according to their weighting.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Global citizenship: Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.
These are in form of in class exercises and online resources which will be available in the VLE.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two summative assessments, with the second split into two components.

a) Assessment 1 (30%): Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the first half of this module (30 sessions). Assessment 1 will be completed online.

b) Assessment 2 (70% in total): This end of module assessment comprises two components: Part A (35%) consists of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the second half of this module (30 sessions). Part B (35%) is a data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. Assessment 2 will be an on-campus exam.

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).   All three assessment components will contribute to the final module mark according to their weighting.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
This module provides students with an insight into higher education, the transition from learning to studying, and an appreciation of Biosciences as the bigger picture. All within the context of establishing the solid foundation upon which to build a degree in whichever area of the Life Sciences a student chooses. This module brings together the core concepts of biology and highlights the importance of the roles they play and the interrelationships between the biological disciplines. In this module students will study biology at the macro and micro levels. A mix of learning & teaching methods will be used in this module which will include, but are not limited to lectures, active learning, and learning through assessment, plus the use of directed reading/multimedia resources. This module will be assessed by a cycle 1 'midterm' assessment comprising mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions (30%). Cycle 2 'end of module assessment' is split into two parts: Part A which will be a similar format to the cycle 1 assessment (35%) and Part B which will comprise a data interpretation assessment. (35%).
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

To provide students with the opportunity to develop their knowledge and understanding of the core concepts in biology applicable to the Life Sciences.

To encourage the students to increase their awareness and appreciation of the ‘bigger picture’ related to the study of Bioscience and the interdisciplinary relationships between the Life science disciplines.

To facilitate the development of knowledge and understating of the Life Sciences to enable students to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge, to solve problems and make informed decisions on their future study pathways.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The transition into higher education can be a challenging one. This module aims to aid students in their journey from further education learners into higher education students of the Life Sciences. To truly appreciate the disciplines which make up the Life Sciences we must first develop an understanding and appreciation of their commonalities. This module brings together the core concepts of biology at the macro through the micro levels. This will provide students with the opportunity to develop and enhance their knowledge of the Life Sciences and the possible pathways which they wish to study further. A mix of learning & teaching methods will be used in this module which will include, but are not limited to lectures, active learning, and learning through assessment, plus the use of directed reading/multimedia resources. This module will be assessed by a midterm assessment comprising mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions (30%). There will also be an end of module assessment which is split into two parts: Part A which will be a similar format to the midterm assessment (35%) and Part B which will comprise a data interpretation assessment (35%).
Outline Syllabus
1. What is University about? Biology, the bigger picture and the parts we play, where do we fit in?

2. Themed introduction to the tree of life (microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals)– introductory overviews of commonality in areas such as (but not limited to) genetic codes, metabolism, small molecules and translational information systems. Similarities and differences between various organisms. Major evolutionary transitions and patterns of life over earth history.

3. The flow of information: what makes everything work? – DNA, RNA, Protein; building blocks and molecular underpinnings; metabolism, energy, efficiency and inefficiency.

4. How do cells replicate? – Mitosis, meiosis, mutation; Bacterial replication, binary fission.

5. How to build an organism? – What are the different organisms and their basis; Prokaryotic, Eurokaryotic (microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals). Introductions to microbial diversity. Development and complexity.

6. Genetics and evolution – Genetics, mutation, selection, natural and sexual selection, genetic drift, genetic diversity, AMR, adaptation and limits; micro and macro evolution. Human origins and diversity

7. Microbial diversity – Introductions to virology, parasitology, bacteriology, and the ways of life; Public and Global health.

8. General principles of pharmacology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts as a baseline and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through on-campus lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as per details below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 60 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.  

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be associated with approx. 4 hours of independent learning. This encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning in preparation for lectures, as well as revision study and work towards assessment.
 
The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g., PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g., Padlet, Miro). Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.  

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.
These are in form of in class exercises and online resources which will be available in the VLE.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two summative assessments, with the second split into two components.

a) Assessment 1 (30%): Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the first half of this module (30 sessions). Assessment 1 will be completed online.

b) Assessment 2 (70% in total): This end of module assessment comprises two components: Part A (35%) consists of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the second half of this module (30 sessions). Part B (35%) is a data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. Assessment 2 will be an on-campus exam.

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).   All three assessment components will contribute to the final module mark according to their weighting.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
This module provides students with an insight into higher education, the transition from learning to studying, and an appreciation of Biosciences as the bigger picture. All within the context of establishing the solid foundation upon which to build a degree in whichever area of the Life Sciences a student chooses. This module brings together the core concepts of biology and highlights the importance of the roles they play and the interrelationships between the biological disciplines. In this module students will study biology at the macro and micro levels. A mix of learning & teaching methods will be used in this module which will include, but are not limited to lectures, active learning, and learning through assessment, plus the use of directed reading/multimedia resources. This module will be assessed by a cycle 1 'midterm' assessment comprising mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions (30%). Cycle 2 'end of module assessment' is split into two parts: Part A which will be a similar format to the cycle 1 assessment (35%) and Part B which will comprise a data interpretation assessment. (35%).
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

To provide students with the opportunity to develop their knowledge and understanding of the core concepts in biology applicable to the Life Sciences.

To encourage the students to increase their awareness and appreciation of the ‘bigger picture’ related to the study of Bioscience and the interdisciplinary relationships between the Life science disciplines.

To facilitate the development of knowledge and understating of the Life Sciences to enable students to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge, to solve problems and make informed decisions on their future study pathways.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The transition into higher education can be a challenging one. This module aims to aid students in their journey from further education learners into higher education students of the Life Sciences. To truly appreciate the disciplines which make up the Life Sciences we must first develop an understanding and appreciation of their commonalities. This module brings together the core concepts of biology at the macro through the micro levels. This will provide students with the opportunity to develop and enhance their knowledge of the Life Sciences and the possible pathways which they wish to study further. A mix of learning & teaching methods will be used in this module which will include, but are not limited to lectures, active learning, and learning through assessment, plus the use of directed reading/multimedia resources. This module will be assessed by a midterm assessment comprising mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions (30%). There will also be an end of module assessment which is split into two parts: Part A which will be a similar format to the midterm assessment (35%) and Part B which will comprise a data interpretation assessment (35%).
Outline Syllabus
1. What is University about? Biology, the bigger picture and the parts we play, where do we fit in?

2. Themed introduction to the tree of life (microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals)– introductory overviews of commonality in areas such as (but not limited to) genetic codes, metabolism, small molecules and translational information systems. Similarities and differences between various organisms. Major evolutionary transitions and patterns of life over earth history.

3. The flow of information: what makes everything work? – DNA, RNA, Protein; building blocks and molecular underpinnings; metabolism, energy, efficiency and inefficiency.

4. How do cells replicate? – Mitosis, meiosis, mutation; Bacterial replication, binary fission.

5. How to build an organism? – What are the different organisms and their basis; Prokaryotic, Eurokaryotic (microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals). Introductions to microbial diversity. Development and complexity.

6. Genetics and evolution – Genetics, mutation, selection, natural and sexual selection, genetic drift, genetic diversity, AMR, adaptation and limits; micro and macro evolution. Human origins and diversity

7. Microbial diversity – Introductions to virology, parasitology, bacteriology, and the ways of life; Public and Global health.

8. General principles of pharmacology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts as a baseline and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through on-campus lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as per details below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 60 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.  

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be associated with approx. 4 hours of independent learning. This encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning in preparation for lectures, as well as revision study and work towards assessment.
 
The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g., PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g., Padlet, Miro). Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.  

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.
These are in form of in class exercises and online resources which will be available in the VLE.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two summative assessments, with the second split into two components.

a) Assessment 1 (30%): Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the first half of this module (30 sessions). Assessment 1 will be completed online.

b) Assessment 2 (70% in total): This end of module assessment comprises two components: Part A (35%) consists of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the second half of this module (30 sessions). Part B (35%) is a data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. Assessment 2 will be an on-campus exam.

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).   All three assessment components will contribute to the final module mark according to their weighting.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
This module provides students with an insight into higher education, the transition from learning to studying, and an appreciation of Biosciences as the bigger picture. All within the context of establishing the solid foundation upon which to build a degree in whichever area of the Life Sciences a student chooses. This module brings together the core concepts of biology and highlights the importance of the roles they play and the interrelationships between the biological disciplines. In this module students will study biology at the macro and micro levels. A mix of learning & teaching methods will be used in this module which will include, but are not limited to lectures, active learning, and learning through assessment, plus the use of directed reading/multimedia resources. This module will be assessed by a cycle 1 'midterm' assessment comprising mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions (30%). Cycle 2 'end of module assessment' is split into two parts: Part A which will be a similar format to the cycle 1 assessment (35%) and Part B which will comprise a data interpretation assessment. (35%).
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

To provide students with the opportunity to develop their knowledge and understanding of the core concepts in biology applicable to the Life Sciences.

To encourage the students to increase their awareness and appreciation of the ‘bigger picture’ related to the study of Bioscience and the interdisciplinary relationships between the Life science disciplines.

To facilitate the development of knowledge and understating of the Life Sciences to enable students to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge, to solve problems and make informed decisions on their future study pathways.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The transition into higher education can be a challenging one. This module aims to aid students in their journey from further education learners into higher education students of the Life Sciences. To truly appreciate the disciplines which make up the Life Sciences we must first develop an understanding and appreciation of their commonalities. This module brings together the core concepts of biology at the macro through the micro levels. This will provide students with the opportunity to develop and enhance their knowledge of the Life Sciences and the possible pathways which they wish to study further. A mix of learning & teaching methods will be used in this module which will include, but are not limited to lectures, active learning, and learning through assessment, plus the use of directed reading/multimedia resources. This module will be assessed by a midterm assessment comprising mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching item questions (30%). There will also be an end of module assessment which is split into two parts: Part A which will be a similar format to the midterm assessment (35%) and Part B which will comprise a data interpretation assessment (35%).
Outline Syllabus
1. What is University about? Biology, the bigger picture and the parts we play, where do we fit in?

2. Themed introduction to the tree of life (microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals)– introductory overviews of commonality in areas such as (but not limited to) genetic codes, metabolism, small molecules and translational information systems. Similarities and differences between various organisms. Major evolutionary transitions and patterns of life over earth history.

3. The flow of information: what makes everything work? – DNA, RNA, Protein; building blocks and molecular underpinnings; metabolism, energy, efficiency and inefficiency.

4. How do cells replicate? – Mitosis, meiosis, mutation; Bacterial replication, binary fission.

5. How to build an organism? – What are the different organisms and their basis; Prokaryotic, Eurokaryotic (microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals). Introductions to microbial diversity. Development and complexity.

6. Genetics and evolution – Genetics, mutation, selection, natural and sexual selection, genetic drift, genetic diversity, AMR, adaptation and limits; micro and macro evolution. Human origins and diversity

7. Microbial diversity – Introductions to virology, parasitology, bacteriology, and the ways of life; Public and Global health.

8. General principles of pharmacology.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:  

This is in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts as a baseline and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  

Lectures:  

The module will be taught through on-campus lectures with an emphasis towards active learning as per details below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 60 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.  

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be associated with approx. 4 hours of independent learning. This encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning in preparation for lectures, as well as revision study and work towards assessment.
 
The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g., PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g., Padlet, Miro). Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.  

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 

Global citizenship: Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recoded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g., global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.
These are in form of in class exercises and online resources which will be available in the VLE.

Summative assessments at regular intervals throughout the course. We expect two summative assessments, with the second split into two components.

a) Assessment 1 (30%): Mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the first half of this module (30 sessions). Assessment 1 will be completed online.

b) Assessment 2 (70% in total): This end of module assessment comprises two components: Part A (35%) consists of mixed multiple choice, multiple answer and matching answer questions covering the materials from the second half of this module (30 sessions). Part B (35%) is a data interpretation exercise in which, for example, a recent publication or data set relating to the module topics is provided to students, who then are expected to answer short answer questions on its content, interpret the data within and, for example, predict scenario outcomes or plan onward research. Assessment 2 will be an on-campus exam.

The data interpretation assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).   All three assessment components will contribute to the final module mark according to their weighting.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
